turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hi there, it's Doctor Smith from Babylon. Can you confirm your name, date of birth and your address, please?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, <UNIN/> date of birth twenty second of december, nineteen ninety. Uh, address, uh, <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> sixteen <UNIN/> avenue.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, that's fine. <UNIN/> Are you in a private place so you can have a consultation?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, sure.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: What can I do for you today?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: So, um, recently I'm wheezy. Uh, I have feel like kind of short of breath.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, and how long has that been going on for?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Mmm, two, three days. Yeah, quite recently.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And have you ever had similar symptoms in the past?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, I think so. It was a while before, yeah, but I can't remember.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: As, was that as an adult or as a child?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Sorry? Oh, as a <UNIN/>, as a adult, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: How long ago was that?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Sorry?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: How long ago was that, that you had similar symptoms?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I can't remember, sorry.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And any problems with wheezing when you were a child or any asthma?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, yes, I had asthma. I also had, uh, <UNIN/> hay fever and <UNIN/> <UNSURE>eczema</UNSURE> <UNIN/>, sorry.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, and <UNIN/> when you were a child how bad was your asthma?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, it's quite bad.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Did you have to take medication?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, I take the asthma inhaler.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Do you know which ones you took?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, I can't remember.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And did you ever have to go to hospital with it?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, sometimes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Did you ever get severely unwell, have to be on intensive care unit or anything like that?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, not that bad but still, sometimes, need to go to hospital to check if it goes well.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Did you have to miss school?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, yeah, occasionally.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And when do you think it last, when do you think that asthma stopped? At what age did you get to a point where you weren't taking medication anymore?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Mmm.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Few years ago, like, three or four years ago I think? Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And so this time, how did it start? Did you have any other symptoms? Any chest pain, temperature, cold symptoms, anything like that?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, so I have, I have cough and cough a lot, and I have a fever. Um, I also used to walk to work but recently I can't because it's, I, I feel like very short of breath and sometimes I feel like I can't even finish <UNIN/> sentence is quite difficult to, to complete the, the the talking sometimes, yeah. Occasionally.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Right. Have you coughed any phlegm up or anything like that?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Any, any, um, blood in there when you cough?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, I don't think so.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And any chest pain?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No chest pain, no.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Have you been woken up at night time at all?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, just daytime working, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Have you been able to do any exercise?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, I can't.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, and do you have a peak flow meter at home, where you measure your breathing?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Sorry?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: You have what's called a peak flow meter, which you breathe into to get a score on your breathing?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, no.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And do you normally take any asthma inhalers over the last few years?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: You do? So you said you stopped them three to four years ago?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Ohh, um, when I had asthma I used to take this inhaler, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. How about over the last three to four years?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Have you taken any medication?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, I took salbutamol? Salbutamol? Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, so you, you normally take that do you? Or is that just recently?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Normally, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, and how often do you normally need it?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Every, every few weeks? I'm not sure.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. What about when you exercise normally, do you have to use medication? Uh, inhalers?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNIN/> Yeah, yeah, a bit.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Pardon?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, um, and do you take any other medications?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, nothing else.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Any other medical problems?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, I have, uh, hay fever as well.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, do you take anything for that?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And any allergies to medications?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, no allergies.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Do you smoke?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, I don't smoke.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Do you drink any alcohol regularly?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, one glass.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: How often? Have a glass of what?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Today, yeah.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, one glass of wine.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Every, how often did you say?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Every two or three days? Depends, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And who do you live with at home?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Who do you live with at home?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Who do you live with, do you live on your own, or do you live with

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I live with my partner.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, and what's your job, day-to-day?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, I'm engineer.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And have you been at work in the last few days?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No I can't because I used to walk <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> walk to work, but recently I, I work from home or sometimes I take sick leave, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, and when, at the moment, are you, um, feeling short of breath when you're sitting still? Or just when you walk?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Just walk or sometimes, but currently I feel, I feel well.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Are you able to get <UNIN/> up and down the stairs OK?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Right, OK. Um, and did you say you were finding it hard to complete your sentences?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, sometimes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, um.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>, days, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Right, OK. Um, I mean, it sounds like you've had a flare up of your asthma. It could be, um, triggered by, if there's more pollen around, or there may be, you may have a viral infection, causing it to get worse.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Mm-hmm.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Mm-hmm.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Did you say you checked your temperature already?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes, I checked, I have fever <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Was it normal?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> What was your temperature?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, thirty seven, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, that's fine. Um, have you got an asthma inhaler at home?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So what I would suggest is you take it more regularly than you are doing at the moment. Have you got, um, a spacer at home?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Mm-hmm.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, do you want to show me how to do it or somehow?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, do you have a spacer at home?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Um, what I can do is, I can prescribe you a peak flow meter so we can check your breathing level and a spacer to use your inhaler a bit more efficiently, which the pharmacist can show you how you use that when you pick it up.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, sure.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, and if you increase it so you're taking it two to four puffs, like, every four hours?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Mm-hmm.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Initially, um, if you get a high temperature or your wheezing is getting worse, you need to call us back straightaway so we can just advise you further with that.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And it will be a good idea when you're feeling better if we can arrange just a review, just to see how your asthma is, because we may need to start some other medication for you.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK, sounds good, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: You could arrange a review in a week or so, um, but, but before that and if you're, if you're feeling worse.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: In a week, right? OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, and the other thing to do would be to take a regular antihistamine.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Mm-hmm.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Which you can get from the pharmacy, I can put a <UNIN/> on your notes about what to take.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, they'll be helpful.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And then if you, when you get the peak flow meter, if you can take, the pharmacist can show you how to use it, and if you can record a value first thing when you wake up.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Mm-hmm.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And in the evening over the next week, and then we can discuss that over the phone when we look at the figures and see whether you need to go on another inhaler as well.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Oh, awesome, thank you.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Have you got any questions?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, no, that's fine, yeah, thank you very much.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Thanks a lot, bye.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>
